awd_abstract_narration:
Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Influence of Politics and Economics on Property Law

Abstract: 

Despite substantial change in recent decades, economic disparities between men and women continue to persist today. Contemporary gender inequalities in economic arenas are linked to a legacy of legal inequalities initially enacted in civil property and family law. This project seeks to examine how and why certain family and property laws were adopted, in order to identify the historical processes that have shaped modern gender inequalities. In doing so, the study will provide insight into economic and political inequality in the United States and globally.

The legal foundations of modern nation states and economies emerged throughout Western societies in the 18th and 19th centuries, as numerous countries adopted nationally standardized civil law regimes with complex systems of property rights. This project will investigate the cross-national and cross-time variation in civil laws in order to identify the political processes informing which laws were adopted. Further, it will test the degree to which conflicts over economic and political resources drove these legal and political outcomes. Empirically, the project will examine developments in France and more broadly in Europe and will produce two novel datasets. The first subnational dataset will leverage a set of documents containing reform demands, written on the eve of France?s 1789 revolution, to create a geographically comprehensive source of public and elite opinions on legal reform and women?s rights. The second dataset will provide cross-national quantitative indicators of women?s property rights in the late 18th and 19th centuries. The project will provide insight into the factors that drive inequality and hierarchy between men and women in law and economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation project, including the analyses made directly possible through the NSF improvement grant, examines the relationship between politics and property. It seeks to understand how women’s political and property rights change over time and how they interact with each other and broader institutional and political changes. The project combines quantitative and qualitative analyses of data, much of which was collected by the author and her research team to produce several notable findings.

The project demonstrates that, surprisingly, some women had both political and property rights prior to the advent of modern political and legal institution. In the French context, the novel data suggests that women (in some classes) may have constituted nearly 10% of participants in local legal and electoral assembly meetings prior to the revolution of 1789. Local assembly records further demonstrate how this participation was tied to women’s property rights and economic activities, which were in turn closely related to the ways in which civil law shaped family structures.

The development of modern political and legal institutions shifted women’s access to political and economic activities, as well as the relationship between them. New political rules largely excluded women from political rights. Modern legal institutions had mixed effects on women’s access to property and its relationship with family structure. Assessing the degree of change is complicated by the fact that previously laws varied dramatically across France. The new Civil Code did not simply invent new laws, it carefully drew together selected older traditions with novel provisions. The most important legal change came through the standardization of law that created uniform rules across France. This slowly encouraged a homogenization in family structure and women’s rights relative to property. Throughout the 19th and 20th centuries the new contours of women’s political rights (or lack thereof) and their property rights continued to interact, with property rights often, though not always, helping to support women’s political activities.   

Finally, the project explores the influence of developments in France on other countries. Modern French civil law served as an important model for many countries across Europe and the globe, who either adopted the French law in its entirety (sometimes by force) or adopted the structure and many provisions when developing their own legal codes. An analysis of family laws across time in different contexts helps to highlight that like in France modern law did not fully invent new provisions. At the same time, law developed through a central authority and/or under the influence of the French model, helped to reinforce and make uniform certain provisions that shaped family structure and women’s rights. As in France, these legal develops appear to be associated women’s political activities.

The findings of this project will have a substantial impact on the theoretical and empirical state of understanding women's rights in the social sciences. It provides new evidence of the historical existence of women's political and property rights and documents a decline in these rights with modern developments in legal and political institutions. In so doing, it challenges a common social science theory and general perception that asserts that women’s rights increase overtime. This perception is fundamental to how we understand and talk about contemporary rights. Identifying the decline in women's rights, moreover, can help us better understand institutional change and safeguard against similar declines in the future. The identified relationships between property rights, civil law, family structure, and political activities further expands our understanding of the important and complicated relationship between politics and property law.
